note: The script is characteristic of 10th century Melkite manuscripts. Two diagonal strokes are used for punctuation. Occasionally, one can see a diacritical dot under the letter /q/ — a fairly common feature in Melkite manuscripts (see, e.g., J. Monferrer-Sala, "Once Again on the Earliest Christian Arabic Apology: Remarks on a Palaeographic Singularity," Journal of Near Eastern Studies 69.2 (2010): 195-197

note.value: Fol. 85 may contain a colophon in which the month of September (Aylul) is mentioned, but this is far from certain
Description of undertext by Alexander Treiger
Bibliography: J. Monferrer-Sala, "Once Again on the Earliest Christian Arabic Apology: Remarks on a Palaeographic Singularity," Journal of Near Eastern Studies 69.2 (2010): 195-197
